Perhaps.  Recognize speciat=
ion for what it was: an attempt to protect
genetic diversity.  Explore the =
possibility that speciation, while
being *A* way to accomplish that goal, m=
ay not be the ONLY way, and it
may not even be the BEST way.  Humans are on=
ly ONE species.  Yet we
have a great deal of genetic diversity.   There mus=
t be a way, within
the species itself, of accomplishing that goal.

The mor=
e I think about it, the more I think that the hard-edged
demarcation of bou=
ndaries is not the best way to go.  The existence of
'variable speciation t=
hreshold' is evidence that such is the case.

If you randomly select from a=
 population, the results of your sample
set should be proportional to the p=
roportions of the population.  We
don't want that.  We want to maintain the=
 genetic diversity.  But, of
course, we want to manage our resource allocat=
ion based on productive
search areas.  So an elegant and flexible method is=
 needed that lets
us control where in this 'diverse' sea of genomes we focu=
s.

What is an elegant (even if it is computationally intense) solution
bes=
ides speciation?

Well, speciation, done right, is basically 'clustering'. =
 Done right,
clustering doesn't have a fixed threshold.  Nor does it have a=
 fixed
cluster count.  Clusters are where clusters are.  Just find them.  S=
o
the work to maintain a fixed number of species probably isn't a good
idea=
.  But you can't have every individual in their own species,
right?  Only b=
ecause of how a species is used to constrain
reproduction.  If reproduction=
 were constrained not by cluster but by
individual pairings of compatible i=
ndividuals, then the whole concept
of a species would not be necessary.  It=
 would, however, be useful for
controlling resource allocation, so an alter=
native / replacement would
be needed.

Say you have 1000 individuals in the=
 population.  Pair them up, and
you have 500 pairs.  Each pair could be com=
bined in multiple ways.  So
each pairing could produce 2-5 (or more) offspr=
ing.  Let's say they
all produce 5 offspring.  You could then re-pair each =
individual with
a different individual.  Repeat however often you like.  Ad=
d to that
elitism, selecting the most fit individuals from each region of t=
he
search space.  Add to that random weight mutations.  And random
topology=
 mutations.

Let's say that your 1000 individuals become, for the sake of a=
rgument,
10,000 individuals.  Now, you don't want to test them all.  So,
in=
stead, you sample the 1000 of them that best represent the whole
search spa=
ce covered by that 10,000, with a little bias for areas of
the search space=
 where the fitness is higher.

The purist that tries to squeeze out every l=
ast bit of performance
from the genome portion of the evolution would proba=
bly call that a
waste of computational resources.  But for a really large a=
nd complex
search space, I propose that this will make for a much more effi=
cient
search that is less likely to get stuck in a local optima.  Thus,
red=
ucing the amount of fitness evaluations (the really expensive part
of any n=
on-trivial domain), you win in the end.

But the only way to know for sure =
is to try it out and see what the
results are.  That means figuring out the=
 right way to do that
'sampling'.  Anybody have any suggestions on how best=
 do do that
representative sampling of the search space covered by the 10,0=
00
individuals?
